Don't tell me. You've come to read  my trousers. On ROYER-COLLARD's face, the utmost contempt; the MARQUIS grins, ear-to-ear.
Don't keep me in suspense. What'll  it be? Fifty lashes? A night on the  rack?
I won't sully my hands with him.
Nor should you. That's the first  rule of politics, isn't it? (a sly insinuation)
The man who orders the execution  never drops the blade.
CLOSE UP: COULMIER, whose face bears all the frustration a new parent, saddled with an incorrigible child.
You're lucky it falls to me to punish  you.
COULMIER paces, to and fro. The MARQUIS, still dressed in his "novel," sits on the floor.
If it were up to the Doctor, you'd  be flayed alive.
A man after my own heart...
What in God's name am I to do with  you?  The more I forbid, the more  you're provoked!
I could be convinced to abandon my  writing, quite voluntarily.
What on earth would that require?
A night spent with the partner of my  choice.
You expect me to pimp Madeleine?
I wasn't talking about Madeleine. The MARQUIS blows a kiss in COULMIER's direction; COULMIE turns a fiery red.
Coulmier, you animal!

head_text.subj: I DO NOT MEAN TO FLIRT, MARQUIS

text: Oh, but you must, my pumpkin! Sex  without flirtation is merely rape!
The MARQUIS begins to undress, hurriedly. First his tailc then his waistcoat.
My shoes; they're naught but  punctuation. COULMIER just glares. THE MARQUIS kicks them off, too. He twists the amber ring off his finger.

My jewels, family or otherwise? Once again, COULMIER refuses to be roped into THE MARQUIS little game.  THE MARQUIS seizes the ring in his teeth, a proffers COULMIER a gritted, ugly smile.  COULMIER plucks the ring out of his maw. THE MARQUIS now stands in nothin but his stockings and trousers.
Your breeches as well. THE MARQUIS unhooks the first button on his breeches, the waits, expectantly, for COULMIER to do the rest.
You started this little game; you  finish it. Or haven't you the courage? COULMIER falters; he wasn't expecting this.
(snorting derisively)
I thought not. He lets his trousers drop. In the dim shadows, the MARQUI is naked now, except for his hair. He sidles up, close, t COULMIER, his breath in the priest's ear:
It's a potent aphrodisiac, isn't it?   Power over another man.
Your wig. Remove your wig.
The MARQUIS slides off his wig, and places it over his  privates, swinging it, like the tail of a horse. COULMIER reaches out and grabs it away.
You'll no longer spread your insidious  gospel, where art's magnitude is the  breadth of its depravity! FROM NOW

head_text.subj: ON, YOU WILL NOT EVEN WRITE YOUR OWN

text: So much anger seethes between them, it's electric.

Are your convictions so fragile that  mine cannot stand in opposition to  them? Is your God so flimsy? So weak?   For shame! The thinnest trace of a smile dances on COULMIER's lips;  he's won this round, and he knows it.

Don't flatter yourself, Marquis. You're not the Anti-Christ.  You're  nothing but a malcontent who knows  how to spell. With that, COULMIER exits with THE MARQUIS' clothing in h arms. THE MARQUIS is left alone, naked and pathetic, in a empty cell. INT. CORRIDOR - MEANWHILE. ROYER-COLLARD storms down the hall toward MADELEINE's  quarters, with VALCOUR, GAILLON and CHARLOTTE on his heel
I saw her with my own eyes.  She put  the key in the latch, just as proud  as you please--

Madeleine's head, framed against the sky Reminiscent of the GUILLOTINE VICTIM in the film's openin sequence. A SECOND HEAD looms into frame. Only--instead o belonging to an EXECUTIONER--this one belongs to VALCOUR.
VALCOUR ties MADELEINE's wrists to the posts of the well the center of the yard. With scissors, he slowly cuts the
laces up the back of her corset, exposing her back. Next, raises a steel-tipped martinet, poised to whip.

She singles out faces: ROYER-COLLARD, who watches imperio from a window above, GAILLON at his side. CHARLOTTE, who  watches the proceedings with smug satisfaction. MADAME  LECLERC, whose foggy eyes are filled with tears. MICHETTE LOUISON, GUERIN and ORVOLLE, all faces ripe with sympathy And--separated by a fence--the LUNATICS--FRANVAL, PITOU,  CLEANTE, and DAUPHIN among them. BOUCHON, a hideous scar on his cheek from the iron, all b drools in anticipation. VALCOUR looks to ROYER-COLLARD for permission to strike;  coolly ROYER-COLLARD grants it. MADELEINE flinches in  anticipation of the blow. It comes down, hard.

As MADELEINE shudders in pain, the DOCTOR can't help hims he quivers--ever so slightly--with pleasure. An angry wel appears on MADELEINE's skin. Then another. She chokes back tears, enduring her punishment with digni COULMIER bursts forth from the CROWD.
VALCOUR stops short; he turns to ROYER-COLLARD. THE DOCTO stands, menacingly.
He'll do no such thing.
It's a weak man who tests his mettle  on the backs of children--
This child let loose the beast from  its cage--
Madeleine's not wicked. It's the  Marquis who's corrupted her. That's  not her fault; it's mine. COULMIER turns to VALCOUR, and whispers urgently:
Your dagger. Give me your dagger. VALCOUR looks to the DOCTOR; which superior should he hon
COULMIER reaches out and slides the dagger from VALCOUR's belt. He slices through the rope that binds MADELEINE; sh grabs him for support, and whispers urgently:
I was wrong to free him, but so are  you--for taking all his treasures-- his quills and his ink--
Not now, or we're both done for. COULMIER turns back to ROYER-COLLARD and shouts:
If only blood will appease you, then  shed mine.
You'd suffer in her stead?
Abbe, no-- COULMIER proffers both fists to VALCOUR.

Go ahead. Bind them. Bind them. Reluctantly, VALCOUR ties Coulmier's hands together. Next he hikes them over the whipping post. He loosens COULMIER vestments, stripping them to the waist. Next, he raises h martinet and turns to ROYER-COLLARD for permission to str
That won't be necessary. A sigh of relief from the CROWD. As VALCOUR frees him,  COULMIER rubs his wrists. ROYER-COLLARD stares at him wit steel eyes.
If you want to martyr yourself, Abbe,  do it for God. Not a chambermaid.  Now put your clothes back on.
COULMIER--chastened--turns a blazing red.

MADELEINE sits on the examining table, her bodice pulled  down around her waist.  A severe-looking NUN prepares sal for the lashes on her back. COULMIER sits behind a small  folding screen--for modesty--and talks to MADELEINE; it t considerable strength of will to keep from peeking at her
Had I known your taste in novels, I  never would've taught you to read.
Don't say that; reading's my  salvation.
But why must you indulge in his  pornography?
It's a hard day's wages, slaving  away for madmen. What I've seen in  life, it takes a lot to hold my  interest. The NUN presses a sponge against a particularly nasty gas
Ow!
But why heap such ghastly fantasies  atop an already ghastly existence?
I put myself in his stories. I play  the parts. Each strumpet, each  murderess.
Why not act the role of heroines  instead? Queen Esther from the Bible,  or St. Joan?
If I wasn't such a bad woman on the  page, Abbe, I'll hazard I couldn't  be such a good woman in life. The NUN has finished dressing her wounds; MADELEINE stand
Through the partition in the screen COULMIER catches a gl of MADELEINE's body: the upturn of her breasts, the soft  slope of her back. He turns away, ashamed.
This is no place for a child like  you.

ROYER-COLLARD sits at a table, ledger before him, MONSIEU PROUIX on one side, GAILLON on the other. Lining up for  payment, various CRAFTSMEN: a BRICKLAYER, perhaps, A  CARPENTER, A GARDENER. The DOCTOR hands a small sheath of bills to a particularly large STONE-MASON. When the STONE MASON steps out of the frame, the DOCTOR is confronted by surprising sight: an incensed RENEE PELAGIE.
Good God, Marquise--
I'm on the brink of bankruptcy; my  husband's resources are all but  exhausted. And to what end, I ask  you? ROYER-COLLARD glances behind her; more MEN await payment.
This is neither the time nor the  place--
If only you'd remained true to our  contract! Opiates, for his nerves!   Restraints! The man warrants a bed  of nails--
(sotto voice)
I can say, with the utmost sincerity,  that every franc you've given me has  been put to sterling use. RENEE PELAGIE glances about the room, taking inventory of its contents.
That much is painfully clear. He stands and announces:
Gentleman, if you'll excuse us...only  a moment...thank you, thank you... Amidst grumbles, GAILLON clears the room, closing the doo behind him. MONSIEUR PROUIX hovers behind it, listening.
You've no right to assault me in  this fashion; I'll call for my  footman.  I'll have you removed--

Am I a cursed woman, Doctor? Must I  be betrayed by every man I meet-- SIMONE appears on the balcony above. She's overheard the  commotion, and senses something is amiss. The DOCTOR shif his gaze, staring up at her; RENEE PELAGIE notices that t DOCTOR's attention has been diverted, and whirls around t face SIMONE.
Ah! This must be the little Madame. SIMONE offers a faint, uncertain smile.
How do you do?
I must confess, I envy you.
Envy me? But why?

Your husband's name brings you honor,  doesn't it? You can walk down the  street without insult; without falling  debris. RENEE PELAGIE's brow darkens with sinister pleasure; she  gestures at the riches in the room:
But suppose the whole world knew  that all this splendor was the result  of fraudulence? Of extortion? SIMONE stares at her husband, alarmed.
Why has she come here?
RENEE PELAGIE continues to address SIMONE, even as she fi her stare upon the DOCTOR.
Public scorn carries a terrible sting.   Trust me. I'm a woman who knows.
It's libelous; you wouldn't dare.
And why not? My fortune, siphoned  away.  My reputation, past repair.  I've nothing left to lose. (her eyes narrowing)
Silence my husband, or you'll come  to know an infamy to rival his own. RENEE PELAGIE glances at SIMONE, who glances at her husba who glowers back at RENEE PELAGIE.

A YOUNG WOMAN navigates the winding streets. In her elega attire--notably the broad-brimmed hat which conceals her  face--she's clearly out of place in this neighborhood. VENDORS in cramped shanties and make-shift stalls cry out THE WOMAN as she passes. Their VOICES fade in and out of another, like a demented chorus. The FIRST is a hairy,  toothless bag o' bones:
Psst...Mademoiselle....I've only a  few doses of Spanish fly left... The WOMAN continues on her way, without glancing back. He cape billows behind her. The SECOND VENDOR is a scurvy li jackal indeed.
Cat-o'-nine-tails here, guaranteed  to raise a welt... The THIRD--a feisty little DWARF--has nothing but herself sell. She coos to the WOMAN:

Curious, aren't you? If I can pleasure  me-self, I can pleasure you, too... At the end of the line, the WOMAN reaches the most decrep booth of all. She reaches to ring the tiny bell, and the  knocker falls off in her hand. She pounds on the door wit
her fist instead. From WITHIN, scurrying sounds. The DOOR cracks open a sliver, and an EYE peers out:
(with an insinuating  lilt)
Yes?
The PAWNBOKER's a sinister fellow with shifty eyes. His  CUSTOMER is none other than SIMONE, the DOCTOR's wife. Sh glances about to ensure that the coast is clear.
(covertly)
I'm in search of a book; perhaps you  know it. She slips the PAWNBROKER a scrap of paper; he reads it, t regards her warily.

I've only got copy left; rescued it  me-self from the bonfire. SIMONE bats her eyes, hopefully. The PAWNBROKER sighs, re under the counter, and pulls up a STRONG BOX, with a chai yoking it to the floor. The PAWNBROKER reaches high on a  shelf for the hidden key.
Please hurry. My husband locks the  door at dusk. THE PAWNBROKER opens the lock, and lifts the lid; in the  box, Justine. SIMONE scrounges in her purse for the requi francs.
Sweet little thing like you shouldn't  be reading such filth anyway.
I grew up in a convent, sir.   Everything I know in the world, I  owe to books. And the book itself almost seems to speak...
"To the young maidens of the world..."
SIMONE is at her vanity, with a letter-opener and a glue  pot. Gently, she loosens the cover off A Lady's Garden of Verse.

"Wrest yourselves free from the  tyranny of virtue, and taste without  shame the pleasures of the flesh..." She slathers it with glue, and starts affixing it to her  newly-purchased copy of the Marquis de Sade.
"Male power lies in the clench of a  fist. But a woman's power lies  elsewhere...
ROYER-COLLARD snoozes in his nightcap. SIMONE has her hea deep in a book: A Lady's Garden of Verse.
"... in the velvet cavity betwixt  her thighs..." The light from her oil lamp irritates THE DOCTOR; he open one eye.
It's late, Simone, darling. Put your  poems aside. SIMONE just licks her forefinger, and turns the page.
PROUIX holds a swatch against the dining room wall for  SIMONE's approval: the Napoleonic crest, in royal blue.
Or--if you prefer--a Florentine  tapestry? SIMONE glances at ROYER-COLLARD, who's preoccupied with t FOREMAN in the atrium. She turns to PROUIX and smiles:
Are you a literary man?
Excuse me? From the folds of her skirt, SIMONE pulls her book.
I so admire men with an appetite  for...books. Intrigued, PROUIX takes the parcel. He opens the book and peers under the false cover. His face turns bright red.
Madame, how could you...have you  actually read this volume?
I've memorized it. Would you like me  to recite? She giggles. PROUIX joins in, knowingly.
There comes a time in a young lady's  life when she has to cast book's  aside, and learn from experience. SIMONE cocks her head at a coy angle:
(a challenge:)
That, Monsieur, requires a teacher.
COULMIER is paying a visit to MADELEINE and MADAME LECLER The OLD WOMAN sips tea; MADELEINE folds laundry.
I've good news; I hope you'll agree. THE TWO WOMEN look to him, expectantly.
I've found employment for you both  with the Widow Rougemont in town. MADELEINE's alarmed; she doesn't want to leave Charenton. COULMIER does his best to keep the news upbeat:
You'll have your own cottage on the  grounds, and ten francs a month to  use as you please.
MADAME LECLERC nearly drops her teacup in delight.
You're more than a priest; you're an  angel! Ain't he, Maddy?
It's because of the Marquis, isn't  it?
In part, yes.
(quietly)
He's not the man who's cast a shadow  here. COULMIER knows what she says is true, but can't admit it.
The Doctor's a respected man, a friend  of the court--
I haven't been to see the Marquis  for ages. And I won't--ever again--I  swear it. I won't speak to him, I  won't even utter his name--

Is that a promise you can truly keep? She can't answer. COULMIER glances at MADAME LECLERC; her blindness gives him license to touch MADELEINE. He stroke her cheek; she presses his hand tightly against her face.
Charenton has changed; it's not safe  for you here.
I've you to look after me, haven't
The place looks immaculate down to the last detail.
"Most Esteemed Dr. Royer-Collard. At  long last, your Chateau is complete."
Through it, we see PROUIX, sitting in an open dressing go at a small cherry-wood secretary, proof-reading a note.
"You'll find everything in its  assigned place."

"The chintz draperies, the English  bell pulls, even the ivory door stops.  Only one detail is missing..." He emits a series of staccato moans followed by a long si SIMONE rises from between the ARCHITECT's legs. Her camis is askew, and her face is aglow.
"...your wife."
Tell him I'm no fool. A prison's  still a prison, even with Chinese  silk and chandeliers.
"By the time you read this, we'll be  long gone; bound for England or points  beyond..."
Tell him--if he uncovers our  whereabouts--you'll slit your wrists  with a razor, and I'll plunge a hat- pin through my heart.
(genuinely touched)
You'd do that, rather than forsake  our love?
No. But tell him I would. PROUIX's face falls. SIMONE's leans over and whispers in ear to console him:
Sign it quickly.  Then you can ravish  me again. On linens for which he so  dearly paid.
PROUIX rebound with puppy-dog eagerness; he traces her li with his forefinger.

Yes, on the satin twill...and then,  I beg you, on the bear-skin rug in  his study...and finally...as a  crowning gesture....we'll leave  puddles of love on the Peruvian  marble! Slowly, he inserts his finger all the way into her mouth. SIMONE sucks on it happily, like an infant nursing a teat

ROYER-COLLARD walks up the impressive steps to the front  door, GAILLON at his heels. Stuck there--with a quill pen letter.  He plucks it, glances back at GAILLON, then star to read. His iron jaw begins to quake.
He rushes through the grand foyer, up the magnificent  staircase.

Lying haphazardly in the center of the mattress: A Ladies Garden of Verse. ROYER-COLLARD makes a grab for it, only turn it over and discover its true contents. A primal cry rises in ROYER-COLLARD's throat. Savagely he rips into th pages with his bare hands, shredding them. THE MARQUIS' w flutter down like snow. They fill the screen

CLOSE UP: THE MARQUIS' FACE, as the words trickle down, t gradually disappear. His hair is sopping wet. His skin is pale blue, lined with purple veins. His teeth chatter, an he sputters for air. A loud CRANK, and he disappears from the frame with a start.

The Marquis, strapped into the calming chair in the dunge GAILLON flips the lever.  THE MARQUIS rises from the frig bath; his expression is one of distilled fury.  He cries ferociously--to an UNSEEN PRESENCE.

Show your face! I've a right to see  my Inquisitor!  You've an aptitude  for torture I really quite admire-- we're cut from the same cloth, you  and I-- GAILLON gives another YANK, dunking THE MARQUIS again wit loud SPLASH. When he rises, THE MARQUIS hisses at GAILLON
It thrills you, doesn't it, to hurt  me thus? Look, you're solid as bone,  you're straining your trousers-- Another dunk, another splash. THE MARQUIS tries a new tac
Stop, I beg you!  I'll write dainty  stories! Odes to Virtue! If even  your God will forgive me, so should  you-- Dunk, splash. Now, THE MARQUIS roars:

head_text.subj: VEXATIONS, THE DEEPER YOU ROOT MY

text: We see the recipient of THE MARQUIS' spleen: peering thro the peephole, ROYER-COLLARD. In his eyes, some small meas of vengeance, sated. He slips out of sight.
MADELEINE tosses and turns on the straw mattress she shar with her mother; perspiration plasters her hair to her fa Finally, she crawls out of bed, and slips out of the room

Torches light the way as MADELEINE moves down the corrido In the distance, we hear sounds previously unassociated w Charenton: the clanking of chains and the wailing of inma Perhaps GAILLON thunders down the hall, PITOU and DAUPHIN under each arm. At last, MADELEINE reaches the ABBE's  quarters, and raps on his door.
COULMIER draws on his robe, and cracks the door. MADELEIN slithers inside. He whispers:

You shouldn't be calling on me, not  at this hour; suppose the  nightwatchman saw you, or the cook-- COULMIER sticks his head out the door, glancing to and fr then closes it tightly; he can't disguise his pleasure at seeing MADELEINE.
(cutting him off:)
Don't turn us out, Abbe.
"Turn you out?" Somewhere, a patient wails in the night; another pounds h head against stone. All Charenton rumbles with discontent
It's a sin against God for me to  refuse your kindness. But my heart's  held fast here...
By whom? The Marquis?
(with a rueful little  laugh)
Mother's not half so blind as you. COULMIER understands the magnitude of MADELEINE's confess he also knows--all to well--its futility:
Madeleine, I....there are certain  things...feelings...we must not voice.
Why not?

They incite us to act. In ways we  should not...cannot...a lesson the  Marquis would do well to learn. MADELEINE's so full of feeling that she starts to cry.   COULMIER reaches for her, and takes her in his arms.
Don't. Shhh. You mustn't... He feels her body against his own. His resistance spent,  they kiss. Abruptly, he pulls back.
Go back to your room. Quickly.
What? What've I done?
Don't come back, not tonight, not  again--
You'll hate me now, won't you? With no choice before him, he lies:
I love you, Madeleine, as a  parishioner--as a child of God-- COULMIER swings open the door. He summons all his willpow

My vows are mine and mine alone. So  are my failings. Forgive me. Stung, MADELEINE stifles a sob. She gives COULMIER a fina hurt look and slips out the door. Alone now, COULMIER tri to walk off his arousal, circling the room like a prisone in a cage. Impulsively, he goes to the door and opens it  again.
He sees the figure of a GIRL, lurking in the shadows.
Madeleine-- Furtively, the GIRL steps forward; it's CHARLOTTE. She sh him an accusatory glare; COULMIER ducks back inside, his  heart pounding.

MADELEINE, still smarting from COULMIER's rejection, walk down the gloomy, forbidding hall. She stops. Somewhere de within, MADELEINE makes a sudden, irrevocable decision. S abruptly turns around, heading toward the MARQUIS.
COULMIER kneels on the floor of his cell, his vestments  lowered around his waist. He prays.  Clutched tightly in hand, a braided scourge.
"...Lead us not into temptation..." He cracks the whip against his bare back; it leaves a wic stripe. His body flinches, but his voice doesn't waver.
"...but deliver us from evil..." And another crack...

location: THE CORRIDOR OUTSIDE THE MARQUIS' QUARTERS

text: MADELEINE watches as VALCOUR turns a corner. Once the coa is clear, she scrambles for her key.
She slips inside. She holds up her candle and--crumpled i the corner--THE MARQUIS. He glances at her, a wounded ani
They've taken your clothes?
They decreed me a savage, and now  they have made me one. MADELEINE--embarrassed--abruptly turns away.
Surely you've seen a man naked.
It's only been described to me. In  your books. She rallies and turns to squint at him, seated in the glo
I must say, in your novels you stoke  the most unrealistic expectations.
You're far crueler than I, my sweet. MADELEINE tosses her shawl to him which he fastens like a skirt around his waist.
The Abbe's sending me away.  He fears  for me here, what with the likes of  you--
Don't be fooled, Madeleine!  He fears  for himself.  He's like a man  starving, and you--ha!--you're like  a pork chop dolloped with heavy cream--
He's a man of God; he's true to his  vows.
First and foremost, he's a MAN. You  remind him of that fact, and he  resents you for it. MADELEINE's brow darkens; she knows it's true.
Don't you see, my sweet? In us, they  see their own appetites, stripped  bare.  And so we are reviled; we are  beaten, we are trounced, we are  ridiculed, and we are silenced. (past hopelessness)
What's to be done? It's the artist's  lot. In MADELEINE, something stirs. An idea.
It needn't be; not if you've another  story.
How do you propose I write it? With  dust, upon the air?
You could whisper it through the  walls of your cell. MADELEINE sees THE MARQUIS perk, ever-so-slightly.
Yes; that's it! A final volley from  us both!
Go on, child.
Tomorrow night, whisper a new tale  to your neighbor, Cleante.  He'll  whisper it to his neighbor Dauphin,  who'll whisper it to his neighbor  Franval---
(getting the idea)
--who'll whisper it to Bouchon--
--whose cell lies next to the linen  cabinet! There, armed with a quill  of my own, I'll commit it to paper!
(with real momentum  now)
Yes! You shall. Of course you shall--
(practically squealing)
A tale more horrible than all the  rest combined!
Something to make the angels weep,  and the Saints to gasp for air...    He kisses her fingers, one by one.
Practice your handwriting, my lovely.   So you'll do my words justice. She nods, even as her eyes fill with happy tears.
A rumble of thunder from overhead; a storm is approaching MADELEINE tugs a sheet off the line. Standing behind it,  COULMIER. MADELEINE--startled--gives a little cry.
Madeleine-- Angrily, tugs down the next sheet.
You don't fear the Marquis' sway on  me.  You fear your own.
COULMIER reaches to take her by the arm:
If you'd grant me a final favor, I'd  like the chance to explain myself--
(nasty, but tinged  with hurt:)
Don't come any closer, Abbe. God's  watching. She grabs her basket by both handles and--insolently--ski COULMIER and heads inside. COULMIER starts to follow, but response she hurries her step.

The sky cracks open with a deafening sound. Lightning cra Rain begins to pelt the stone walls of Charenton. INT. THE LINEN PANTRY - A SHORT TIME LATER. MADELEINE swings open the door and sets down her laundry  basket. She lights a small wall sconce, filling the room  with an orange glow. She closes the door behind her. Next she clears a space for herself on a small sewing table,  pushing aside a pin-cushion, bolts of thread, and a heavy pair of scissors. She lifts a sheet off the top of the ba Under it, a stack of parchment, an inkwell, and a quill. removes each item, one-by-one. An EYEBALL watches her eve move.

BOUCHON's hunched on the floor, peering through the old w door. A belt hoists his sack-cloth trousers above his wai He's been dislodging bricks from the interior of his cell wall to reveal the hidden door to the pantry.
The MARQUIS dislodges a small stone from the wall, and pe into the neighboring cell.
Psst...Cleante! Are you there? ARE
CLEANTE is a study in nervous tics; his eyes blink, his e wiggle, and his mouth quivers.
Marquis? Is that you?
For fuck's sake, who else would it  be? The witching hour's arrived;  you've alerted the others, yes?
I'm no longer a man! I awoke to  discover I'd turned into a sparrow! CLEANTE begins to warble. THE MARQUIS stares through the  wall at CLEANTE, eye-to-eye. His words are hypnotic:
Yes, well, I awoke to discover I'd  turned into a cat. If you don't do  as I say, I'll sink my little fangs  into your drumsticks, and suck the  marrow straight out of your bones.
(trembling convulsively)
At your service, Count.
Now give the signal. CLEANTE lets loose with a piercing trill, to alert his  compatriots.
He sparks to the sound; at last, it's time!
He looks up from his reading, candle in hand.
Even he registers the whistle with a low grunt.
MADELEINE whispers a tiny prayer, clutching the ink pot t her bosom.
And so we begin... With a certain improvisatory relish, THE MARQUIS begins t spin his tale:

"Our story concerns the prostitute  Fanchon, whom Nature equipped with a  tight and downy fissure between her  thighs, and the most finely cleft  ass ever moulded by the hand of  God..." Through the chink, THE MARQUIS hears CLEANTE moaning, eve so softly, masturbating to the tale. THE MARQUIS barks:
CLEANTE springs into action, rushing to the opposite side the room and perching on a chair. He whispers through a h by a beam in the ceiling:
"Fanchon was a prostitute with a  tight and downy fissure between her  thighs..." He starts to forget the phrase; THE MARQUIS hisses from a the room:
...the most finely cleft ass...
Under his breath, THE MARQUIS frets:
My glorious prose, filtered through  the minds of the insane? (a sudden, consoling  thought)
Who knows? They might improve it.
DAUPHIN crouches, listening, as CLEANTE transmits the wor
"...and the most finely cleft ass  ever moulded by the hand of God!" He scurries across the room to relay the words to--

"...a harlot, she was, name of  Fanchon, with a downy fissure and a  heavenly ass..." FRANVAL lopes over to the wall he shares with BOUCHON. He removes a small sculptured crucifix, revealing a gap in t stone.
Psst...Bouchon....
BOUCHON' still busy peeping on MADELEINE, heedless of FRA
Distracted, BOUCHON turns in the direction of FRANVAL's v FRANVAL has to whisper loudly so the story carries:
"...'S about a harlot named Fanchon,  with a downy fissure and a heavenly  ass...." BOUCHON'S LIPS CURL IN A GRIN.
Bouchon! You've something for me,  haven't you? Almost shyly, BOUCHON ekes out the words:
"...a downy fissure, and a heavenly  ass..."
(urgently)
You must remember each word, exactly  as it's told to you. Yes? Yes?
"One day, Fanchon's first client was  a surgeon.  He ran his fingers across  her naked skin, pulling apart folds  of flesh, inspecting each and every  follicle..."

--and the listless ones do the  binding.

Thank-you, Charlotte. CHARLOTTE turns coquettish; she and the DOCTOR exchange a telling smile; theirs is more than a professional allianc

VALCOUR and GAILLON load crates of books onto wagons. MICHETTE--idling by the well--watches as the COACHMEN dep charging toward Paris and beyond.

My successor? COULMIER barks a scabrous laugh, then abruptly changes hi tone. He presses himself against the door, and implores D
Listen to me, Abbe, and listen well. He casts a sidelong glance in ROYER-COLLARD's direction:

(back to the ABBE:)

Gibberish, my friend. He rants and  he raves-- COULMIER offers the DU MAUPAS a challenge, urging him to  defy ROYER-COLLARD:
Prove you've an ounce of Christian  charity...Bring me parchment...ink...  and a quill. ABBE DU MAUPAS looks to the DOCTOR; what should he do?

You'll do no such thing. This patient  poses a grave danger, to himself and  to others. With lightning speed, COULMIER reaches through the peepho grabbing ROYER-COLLARD by the collar. His employer, or the mad prophet in the cell? Impulsively acts, loosening COULMIER's grip on the DOCTOR. ROYER-COLL gasps for air.
Are you all right, sir?
Don't you see--
(interrupting)
